channel.title: Eno Docs
channel.generator: Webpage HTML Export plugin for Obsidian

item.title: Introduction
item.description:
This challenge is designed to expose you too many different penetration testing tools, and Linux command-line usage. Each stop has a specific task, with 1 available hint.
To start, login to Cloud9 as:

You will be working from the CyberChallenge virtual machine. if you don't see that virtual machine, ask an admin for access. Your first task is to login to the desktop.
Hint The virtual machine uses the default kali login credentials.

item.title: Stop 1
item.description:
You've made it into the desktop! Your next task is to open a terminal and identify your IP address. There are several ways to do this, use whatever you prefer.
Hint Use any of these commands (additional arguments may be required):
ip addr
hostname

item.title: Stop 2
item.description:
Now that you know your IP address, we get to the fun parts. Using nmap, identify other clients on your local network.
Hint running nmap --help will show you many useful options.

item.title: Stop 3
item.description:
Using the nmap scan data, look for the webserver and navigate to it in a web browser.
Hint This server also has an open SSH port.

item.title: Stop 4
item.description:
Now that you've found the webserver, see if you can find any hidden pages.
Hint Many websites have a sitemap, maybe try starting there.

item.title: Stop 5
item.description:
Once you find the hidden folder, look through the contents of the files. Note the contents of each. Which file has movie reference?
Hint It's a Star Wars reference

item.title: Stop 6
item.description:
Now take a look at the other file available, it looks like gibberish right? That is actually a hash, a one-way cipher that is used to store sensitive information. Download that, and use the tools available to break it.
Hint You will need to use hashcat and the rockyou.txt wordlist, these are both already downloaded, you just need to find them. hashcat -h may show some useful info.

item.title: Stop 7
item.description:
Now that you have the password, login to that webserver via SSH.
Hint The username is not kali, but it is similar to the password.

item.title: Stop 8
item.description:
Now that you're in the webserver, look around for any files that may have useful information.
Hint Make sure to check for hidden files

item.title: Stop 9
item.description:
By now you've spotted several hidden files, one of them is encrypted. What you don't have is how they were encrypted. See if you can find the command used to encrypt them.
Hint Linux keeps a log of all commands run (it's hidden)

item.title: Stop 10
item.description:
You've got all the pieces! Decrypt the file and read its contents.
Hint Only 1 letter needs to be changed from the encryption command to decrypt. (not including file name)

item.title: zSolutions
item.description:
Introduction Username: kali
Password: kali
Stop 1 IP Address will vary, will be 192.168.10.XXX
Stop 2 nmap 192.168.10.0/24
Stop 3 Open http://192.168.10.5 in a web browser.
Stop 4 Open http://192.168.10.5/sitemap.xml and navigate to http://192.168.10.5/fileDirect
Stop 5 text.txt has the Star Wars reference.
Stop 6 Download hash.txt
sudo gzip -d /usr/share/wordlists/rockyou.txt,gz
sudo hashcat -m 0 -o output.txt -a 0 ~/Downloads/hash.txt /usr/share/wordlists/rockyou.txt
cat output.txt
should show hash:John.Cena
Stop 7 ssh 192.168.10.5 -l john, then enter the password you just cracked.
Stop 8 ls -la, look for the file .hidden.txt.cpt
Stop 9 cat ~/.bash_history
Stop 10 ccrypt -d -K "and_his_name_is" .hidden.txt.cpt
cat .hidden.txt

item.title: Router Configuration Reference
item.description:
Connor S
Andrew B

Create VLANS on switchs
Configure Global Interface

int (PORT)
no shut
exit
Configure sub Interfaces

int (PORT).(VLAN)
encapsulation dot1q (VLAN)
ip address (default gateway for the VLAN)
exit

item.title: Switch Configuration Reference
item.description:
Connor S
Andrew B


initialize vlan

int vlan (nber)
name (name)
assign vlan to port

int (port)
switchport mode access
switchport access vlan (number)
configure trunk

int (port)
switchport mode access
switchport trunk allowed vlan (vlan range)

item.title: Proxmox-VM
item.description:
Connor S

Our Proxmox server is considered a bare-metal VM server (Cloud9), the hypervisor runs directly on the hardware with no operating sysetm in between.



Navigate to https://192.168.30.8:8006/ you MUST include https://
Use the following login credentials


Select Login
Select OK



Select Create VM in the top right

Give your VM a name and select Next

Click the box next to ISO Image and select an operating system to install

Select the relevant type and version of your operating system and select Next
Change SeaBIOS to OVMF, and use vmpool for EFI storage. Check Add TPM, and use vmpool for TPM Storage.

Increase disk size to 64, change SCSI to SATA and select Next

Increase the number of cores to 2, and change type to host, then select Next

Increase memory to 4096, then select Next

In the network tab, select vmbr1 as the bridge, and Intel E1000 as the model.

Select Next and then Finish


On the left side of the screen, click the arrow next to Cloud9 to see the list of VMs

Select your VM, then select Console

Press Start Now and enjoy your VM

item.title: Virtualization Overview
item.description:
Connor S

Virtual machines are basically computers running computers. aka computerception
These guides walk you through the different virtual machine types and how to set them up.

item.title: Guides
item.description:
Connor S
Andrew B

A collection of guides for labs and/or room maitanence.

item.title: Comcast Modem
item.description:
Connor S

The Comcast modem has been reduced to nothing but a modem in bridge mode. It should never need to be touch, but it is accessible at http://10.1.10.1 if needed.

item.title: Detailed Network Explanation
item.description:
Connor S

A detailed look at the networking that runs the CIS room.
Quick Overview
Line from street ---> Comcast Modem at Hackler Gym ---> Netgate Firewall ---> Mikrotik L3 Core Switch

The Mikrotik L3 Core Switch divides the network into 3 VLANs:


The Class VLAN is where all of the Work PCs are connected.

The Server VLAN is where all long-term Server Overview's are connected. They



The Lab VLAN is designed to be independent from the rest of the room, where students can work on projects with little to no consequences. It is completely isolated from the rest of the room, and cannot communicate with anything except for the internet.

item.title: Mikrotik L3 Core Switch
item.description:
Connor S

Start typing here...

item.title: Netgate Firewall
item.description:
Connor S

Our firewall is a Netgate 1100.

item.title: Network Overview
item.description:
Connor S


Our internet comes in from the street over at the Hackler Gymnasium. There is a Comcast router there, which we try not to touch because it is old. From there a cable runs from the Gym to the Low Building, and it comes into our backroom.
It goes directly into our firewall, which then runs into a Mikrotik Layer 3 Capable Switch. From there it is divided into 3 networks explained below:

Lab - Mess around here
Class - Don't mess around here, people need internet
Server - All servers go here, please don't touch
A more Detailed Network Explanation is available.

item.title: Cloud9
item.description:
Connor S

Cloud9 is the virtualization server. It runs Proxmox, and is accessed at https://192.168.10.8:8006.

CPU: AMD Ryzen 9 5950X
RAM: 64GB (2 x 32GB) DDR4
Motherboard:
GPU: GTX 1060
PSU:
Case:
Storage:

1x Samsung 970 Evo 500GB
3x Seagate 8TB 7200 RPM
Software RAID 0

Cloud9 hosts several servers as VMs:

Tailscale (VM ID 101) - Remote access VPN server
Hampstead (VM ID 103) - Webserver (hosts this site)
uptime (VM ID 104) - Hosts uptime kuma docker container, accessible at https://192.168.30.11:3001

item.title: Cyberdyne
item.description:
Connor S

Cyberdyne is the core of the CIS class. It runs Windows Server 2019, and provides Domain Services to the entire class.

CPU: AMD EPYC 7401P
RAM: Crucial 64GB (4 x 16GB) DDR4 ECC Registered 2133
Motherboard: Supermicro H11SSL-i
GPU: GTX 1650 Low Profile
PSU: Seasonic PRIME 80+ Titanium 650W
Case: SilverStone Technology CS380 8-Bay Compact ATX Tower case
Storage:

1x Samsung 980 Pro 1TB
8x Seagate IronWolf Pro 4TB 7200 RPM
- 2 Hardware RAID 5's of 4 drives each
- Each RAID 5 is combined into a stripped 22 TB array in windows
Network adapter: TP-Link TX401 10GB PCIe Network Card

All user accounts are stored on Cyberdyne, and allows a student to log in to their account on any computer enrolled in the domain.

Cyberdyne also provides domain DNS related services.



No settings defined.













































































Scheduled Task (At least Windows 7): auto_shutdown

item.title: Funion Server
item.description: Connor S

item.title: Hampstead
item.description:
Connor S
Hampstead is virtual machine on Cloud9, running Ubuntu Server.

item.title: Kronos
item.description:
Connor S

Kronos is a high-speed storage server. It has 4x 2TB NVMe SSDs in a RAID 0. It is used to store non-critical, but useful information.

item.title: Server Overview's
item.description:
Connor S

The CIS program has a small number of computers that act as servers, each serves a specific role.

Cyberdyne - Active Directory, DNS
Cloud9 - Proxmox virtual machine server
Hampstead - Webserver
Kronos - High-speed storage
Tailscale - Remote VPN access/entry point
Uptime - Uptime Kuma docker container for network uptime monitoring
Funion Server - Security Onion node for IDS

item.title: Tailscale
item.description: Connor S

item.title: Uptime
item.description:
Connor S
The uptime server runs an uptime-kuma docker container. It is accessible at http://192.168.30.11:3001.
It is configured to perform ping tests on the following equipment

Class Infrastructure
Class AP
Printer
Core Infrastructure
Class Switch 1
Class Switch 2
Class Switch 3
Comcast Modem
Mikrotik Class VLAN
Mikrotik Server VLAN
Netgate Firewall
Internet Services
Cloudflare
Google
Servers
AD DNS
Cloud9
Cyberdyne
Funion Server
Kronos
Tailscale

item.title: Programs
item.description:
Connor S


Below is the list of all software tools with descriptions installed by default on the golden image.

Chrome - Web browser
Firefox - Web browser
VLC Media Player - Media player
Steam - Game launcher
Spotify - Music service
Discord - Chat service
7-Zip - Archive manager
Notepad++ - Advanced text editor
PuTTY - Remote connection tool
Python 3.11.1 (python.org) - Code interpreter
Anki - Flashcard software
VirtualBox - Virtual Machine manager
Teraterm - Remote connection tool
VS Code - Simple code editor
Git 2.39 - Version control software
Wireshark - Network packet sniffer
Angry IP Scan - Network device scanner
Advance IP Scanner - Network device scanner
Nmap - Network device scanner
Packet Tracer 8.2 - Cisco network simulation tool

Below is an install script to install all tools with the exception of Cisco Packet Tracer
winget install Google.Chrome --scope machine -h winget install Mozilla.Firefox --scope machine -h winget install VideoLAN.VLC --scope machine -h winget install Valve.Steam --scope machine -h winget install Spotify.Spotify --scope machine -h winget install Discord.Discord --scope machine -h winget install 7zip.7zip --scope machine -h winget install Notepad++.Notepad++ --scope machine -h winget install PuTTY.PuTTY --scope machine -h winget install Python.Python.3.12.3 --scope machine -h winget install Anki.Anki --scope machine -h winget install Oracle.VirtualBox --scope machine -h winget install TeraTermProject.teraterm --scope machine -h winget install Microsoft.VisualStudioCode --scope machine -h winget install Git.Git --scope machine -h winget install WiresharkFoundation.Wireshark --scope machine -h winget install angryziber.AngryIPScanner --scope machine -h winget install Famatech.AdvancedIPScanner --scope machine -h winget install Insecure.Nmap --scope machine -h pause

item.title: Work PCs
item.description:
Connor S

The current class work PCs are Minisforum Venus UM773 Lite's. They have the following specs:

CPU: AMD Ryzen 7 7735HS
Graphics: AMD Radeon 680M
RAM: 32 GB DDR5
Storage: 1 TB NVMe SSD
OS: Windows 11 Pro
Wi-Fi/Bluetooth: Wi-Fi 6, BT 5.2
Ports/Buttons:
RJ45 2.5 Gigabit Ethernet Port ×1
USB3.2 Gen2 Type-C ×1 (Data Transfer, Right)
USB3.2 Gen2 Type-A ×2
USB2.0 Type-A ×2
USB4 Type-C ×1 (Left)
HDMI ×2
Clear CMOS ×1
DMIC ×1
3.5mm Combo Jack ×1
